properties.Title: Undeclared Naval War with France
properties.Descr_1: Undeclared Naval War with France. This contest included land actions, such as that in the Dominican Republic, city of Puerto Plata, where marines captured a French privateer under the guns of the forts. Congress authorized military action through a seri
properties.Descr2: es of statutes.

properties.Title: Tripoli
properties.Descr_1: Tripoli. The First Barbary War included the U.S.S. George Washington and Philadelphia affairs and the Eaton expedition, during which a few marines landed with United States Agent William Eaton to raise a force against Tripoli in an effort to free the cr
properties.Descr2: ew of the Philadelphia. Tripoli declared war but not the United States, although Congress authorized U.S. military action by statute.

properties.Title: Mexico (Spanish Territory)
properties.Descr_1: Mexico (Spanish territory). Capt. Z. M. Pike, with a platoon of troops, invaded Spanish territory at the headwaters of the Rio Grande on orders from Gen. James Wilkinson. He was made prisoner without resistance at a fort he constructed in present day Co
properties.Descr2: lorado, taken to Mexico, and later released after seizure of his papers.

properties.Title: Gulf of Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Gulf of Mexico. American gunboats operated from New Orleans against Spanish and French privateers off the Mississippi Delta, chiefly under Capt. John Shaw and Master Commandant David Porter.

properties.Title: West Florida (Spanish Territory)
properties.Descr_1: West Florida (Spanish territory). Gov. Claiborne of Louisiana, on orders of the President, occupied with troops territory in dispute east of the Mississippi River as far as the Pearl River, later the eastern boundary of Louisiana. He was authorized to s
properties.Descr2: eize as far east as the Perdido River.

properties.Title: West Florida (Spanish Territory)
properties.Descr_1: West Florida (Spanish territory). Gov. Claiborne of Louisiana, on orders of the President, occupied with troops territory in dispute east of the Mississippi River as far as the Pearl River, later the eastern boundary of Louisiana. He was authorized to s
properties.Descr2: eize as far east as the Perdido River.

properties.Title: Amelia Island and other parts of east Florida, then under Spain
properties.Descr_1: Amelia Island and other parts of east Florida, then under Spain. Temporary possession was authorized by President Madison and by Congress, to prevent occupation by any other power; but possession was obtained by Gen. George Matthews in so irregular a ma
properties.Descr2: nner that his measures were disavowed by the President.

properties.Title: War of 1812. On June 18, 1812, the United States declared war between the United States and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
properties.Descr_1: War of 1812. On June 18, 1812, the United States declared war between the United States and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. Among the issues leading to the war were British interception of neutral ships and blockades of the United State
properties.Descr2: s during British hostilities with France.

properties.Title: West Florida (Spanish Territory)
properties.Descr_1: West Florida (Spanish territory). On authority given by Congress, General Wilkinson seized Mobile Bay in April with 600 soldiers. A small Spanish garrison gave way. The U.S. advanced into disputed territory to the Perdido River, as projected in 1810. No
properties.Descr2: fighting.

properties.Title: Marquesas Islands
properties.Descr_1: Marquesas Islands. U.S. forces built a fort on the island of Nukahiva to protect three prize ships which had been captured from the British.

properties.Title: Spanish Florida
properties.Descr_1: Spanish Florida. Gen. Andrew Jackson took Pensacola and drove out the British with whom the United States was at war.

properties.Title: Caribbean
properties.Descr_1: Caribbean. Engagements between pirates and American ships or squadrons took place repeatedly especially ashore and offshore about Cuba, Puerto Rico, Santo Domingo, and Yucatan. Three thousand pirate attacks on merchantmen were reported between 1815 and
properties.Descr2: 1823.  In 1822 Commodore James Biddle employed a squadron of two frigates, four sloops of war, two brigs, four schooners, and two gunboats in the West Indies.

properties.Title: Algiers
properties.Descr_1: Algiers. The second Barbary War was declared against the United States by the Dey of Algiers of the Barbary states, an act not reciprocated by the United States. Congress did authorize a military expedition by statutes. A large fleet under Decatur attac
properties.Descr2: ked Algiers and obtained indemnities.

properties.Title: Tripoli
properties.Descr_1: Tripoli. After securing an agreement from Algiers, Decatur demonstrated with his squadron at Tunis and Tripoli, where he secured indemnities for offenses during the War of 1812.

properties.Title: Tripoli
properties.Descr_1: Tripoli. After securing an agreement from Algiers, Decatur demonstrated with his squadron at Tunis and Tripoli, where he secured indemnities for offenses during the War of 1812.

properties.Title: Spanish Florida
properties.Descr_1: Spanish Florida. United States forces destroyed Nicholls Fort, called also Negro Fort, which harbored raiders making forays into United States territory.

properties.Title: Spanish Florida, First Seminole War
properties.Descr_1: Spanish Florida - First Seminole War. The Seminole Indians, whose area was a haven for escaped slaves and border ruffians, were attacked by troops under Generals Jackson and Gaines and pursued into northern Florida. Spanish posts were attacked and occup
properties.Descr2: ied, British citizens executed. In 1819 the Floridas were ceded to the United States.

properties.Title: Amelia Island (Spanish territory off Florida)
properties.Descr_1: Amelia Island (Spanish territory off Florida). Under orders of President Monroe, United States forces landed and expelled a group of smugglers, adventurers, and freebooters.

properties.Title: Oregon
properties.Descr_1: Oregon. The U.S.S. Ontario, dispatched from Washington, landed at the Columbia River and in August took possession of Oregon territory. Britain had conceded sovereignty but Russia and Spain asserted claims to the area.

properties.Title: Africa
properties.Descr_1: Africa. Naval units raided the slave traffic pursuant to the 1819 act of Congress.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. United States naval forces suppressing piracy landed on the northwest coast of Cuba and burned a pirate station.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. Brief landings in pursuit of pirates occurred April 8 near Escondido; April 16 near Cayo Blanco; July 11 at Siquapa Bay; July 21 at Cape Cruz; and October 23 at Camrioca.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. Brief landings in pursuit of pirates occurred April 8 near Escondido; April 16 near Cayo Blanco; July 11 at Siquapa Bay; July 21 at Cape Cruz; and October 23 at Camrioca.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. Brief landings in pursuit of pirates occurred April 8 near Escondido; April 16 near Cayo Blanco; July 11 at Siquapa Bay; July 21 at Cape Cruz; and October 23 at Camrioca.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. Brief landings in pursuit of pirates occurred April 8 near Escondido; April 16 near Cayo Blanco; July 11 at Siquapa Bay; July 21 at Cape Cruz; and October 23 at Camrioca.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. Brief landings in pursuit of pirates occurred April 8 near Escondido; April 16 near Cayo Blanco; July 11 at Siquapa Bay; July 21 at Cape Cruz; and October 23 at Camrioca.

properties.Title: Puerto Rico (Spanish territory)
properties.Descr_1: Puerto Rico (Spanish territory). Commodore David Porter with a landing party attacked the town of Fajardo which had sheltered pirates and insulted American naval officers. He landed with 200 men in November and forced an apology. Commodore Porter was la
properties.Descr2: ter court-martialed for overstepping his powers.

properties.Title: Greece
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. In March cooperating American and British forces landed at Sagua La Grande to capture pirates.

properties.Title: Greece
properties.Descr_1: Greece. In October and November landing parties hunted pirates on the islands of Argenteire, Miconi, and Androse.

properties.Title: Greece
properties.Descr_1: Greece. In October and November landing parties hunted pirates on the islands of Argenteire, Miconi, and Androse.

properties.Title: Falkland Islands
properties.Descr_1: Falkland Islands. Captain Duncan of the U.S.S. Lexington investigated the capture of three American sealing vessels and sought to protect American interests.

properties.Title: Sumatra
properties.Descr_1: Sumatra. February 6 to 9. A naval force landed and stormed a fort to punish natives of the town of Quallah Battoo for plundering the American ship Friendship.

properties.Title: Argentina
properties.Descr_1: Argentina. October 31 to November 15. A force was sent ashore at Buenos Aires to protect the interests of the United States and other countries during an insurrection.

properties.Title: Peru
properties.Descr_1: Peru. December 10, 1835, to January 24, 1836, and August 31 to December 7, 1836. Marines protected American interests in Callao and Lima during an attempted revolution.

properties.Title: Peru
properties.Descr_1: Peru. December 10, 1835, to January 24, 1836, and August 31 to December 7, 1836. Marines protected American interests in Callao and Lima during an attempted revolution.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. General Gaines occupied Nacogdoches (Tex.), disputed territory, from July to December during the Texan war for independence, under orders to cross the “imaginary boundary line” if an Indian outbreak threatened.

properties.Title: Sumatra
properties.Descr_1: Sumatra. December 24, 1838, to January 4, 1839. A naval force landed to punish natives of the towns of Quallah Battoo and Muckie (Mukki) for depredations on American shipping.

properties.Title: Sumatra
properties.Descr_1: Sumatra. December 24, 1838, to January 4, 1839. A naval force landed to punish natives of the towns of Quallah Battoo and Muckie (Mukki) for depredations on American shipping.

properties.Title: Fiji Islands
properties.Descr_1: Fiji Islands. July. Naval forces landed to punish natives for attacking American exploring and surveying parties.

properties.Title: Drummond Island, Kingsmill Group
properties.Descr_1: Drummond Island, Kingsmill Group. A naval party landed to avenge the murder of a seaman by the natives.

properties.Title: Samoa
properties.Descr_1: Samoa. February 24. A naval party landed and burned towns after the murder of an American seaman on Upolu Island.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. Commodore T.A.C. Jones, in command of a squadron long cruising off California, occupied Monterey, Calif., on October 19, believing war had come. He discovered peace, withdrew, and saluted. A similar incident occurred a week later at San Diego.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. Commodore T.A.C. Jones, in command of a squadron long cruising off California, occupied Monterey, Calif., on October 19, believing war had come. He discovered peace, withdrew, and saluted. A similar incident occurred a week later at San Diego.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Sailors and marines from the St. Louis were landed after a clash between Americans and Chinese at the trading post in Canton.

properties.Title: Africa
properties.Descr_1: Africa. November 29 to December 16. Four United States vessels demonstrated and landed various parties (one of 200 marines and sailors) to discourage piracy and the slave trade along the Ivory coast, and to punish attacks by the natives on American seam
properties.Descr2: en and shipping.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. President Tyler deployed U.S. forces to protect Texas against Mexico, pending Senate approval of a treaty of annexation. (Later rejected.) He defended his action against a Senate resolution of inquiry.

properties.Title: Mexican War
properties.Descr_1: Mexican War. On May 13, 1846, the United States recognized the existence of a state of war with Mexico. After the annexation of Texas in 1845, the United States and Mexico failed to resolve a boundary dispute and President Polk said that it was necessar
properties.Descr2: y to deploy forces in Mexico to meet a threatened invasion.

properties.Title: Smyrna
properties.Descr_1: Smyrna. In July a naval force gained release of an American seized by Austrian officials.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. After a massacre of foreigners (including Americans) at Jaffa in January, a demonstration by the Mediterranean Squadron was ordered along the Turkish (Levant) coast.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. After a massacre of foreigners (including Americans) at Jaffa in January, a demonstration by the Mediterranean Squadron was ordered along the Turkish (Levant) coast.

properties.Title: Argentina
properties.Descr_1: Argentina. February 3 to 12, 1852; September 17, 1852 to April 1853. Marines were landed and maintained in Buenos Aires to protect American interests during a revolution.

properties.Title: Argentina
properties.Descr_1: Argentina. February 3 to 12, 1852; September 17, 1852 to April 1853. Marines were landed and maintained in Buenos Aires to protect American interests during a revolution.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. March 11 to 13. U.S. forces landed to protect American lives and interests during political disturbances.

properties.Title: Japan
properties.Descr_1: Japan. Commodore Perry and his naval expedition made a display of force leading to the “opening of Japan.”

properties.Title: Ryukyu and Bonin Islands
properties.Descr_1: Ryukyu and Bonin Islands. Commodore Perry on three visits before going to Japan and while waiting for a reply from Japan made a naval demonstration, landing marines twice, and secured a coaling concession from the ruler of Naha on Okinawa; he also demon
properties.Descr2: strated in the Bonin Islands with the purpose of securing facilities for commerce.

properties.Title: Ryukyu and Bonin Islands
properties.Descr_1: Ryukyu and Bonin Islands. Commodore Perry on three visits before going to Japan and while waiting for a reply from Japan made a naval demonstration, landing marines twice, and secured a coaling concession from the ruler of Naha on Okinawa; he also demon
properties.Descr2: strated in the Bonin Islands with the purpose of securing facilities for commerce.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. April 4 to June 15 to 17. American and English ships landed forces to protect American interests in and near Shanghai during Chinese civil strife.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. May 19 to 21. U.S. forces protected American interests in Shanghai and, from August 3 to 5 fought pirates near Hong Kong.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. May 19 to 21. U.S. forces protected American interests in Shanghai and, from August 3 to 5 fought pirates near Hong Kong.

properties.Title: Fiji Islands
properties.Descr_1: Fiji Islands. September 12 to November 4. An American naval force landed to seek reparations for depredations on American residents and seamen.

properties.Title: Uruguay
properties.Descr_1: Uruguay. November 25 to 29. United States and European naval forces landed to protect American interests during an attempted revolution in Montevideo.

properties.Title: Panama, Republic of New Grenada
properties.Descr_1: Panama, Republic of New Grenada. September 19 to 22. U.S. forces landed to protect American interests during an insurrection.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. October 22 to December 6. U.S. forces landed to protect American interests at Canton during hostilities between the British and the Chinese, and to avenge an assault upon an unarmed boat displaying the United States flag.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. April to May, November to December. In May Commander C.H. Davis of the United States Navy, with some marines, received the surrender of William Walker, who had been attempting to get control of the country, and protected his men from the reta
properties.Descr2: liation of native allies who had been fighting Walker. In November and December of the same year United States vessels Saratoga, Wabash, and Fulton opposed another attempt of William Walker on Nicaragua. Commodore Hiram Paulding’s act of landing marines
properties.Descr3: and compelling the removal of Walker to the United States, was tacitly disavowed by Secretary of State Lewis Cass, and Paulding was forced into retirement.

properties.Title: Nicaragua

properties.Descr2: liation of native allies who had been fighting Walker. In November and December of the same year United States vessels Saratoga, Wabash, and Fulton opposed another attempt of William Walker on Nicaragua. Commodore Hiram Paulding’s act of landing marines
properties.Descr3: and compelling the removal of Walker to the United States, was tacitly disavowed by Secretary of State Lewis Cass, and Paulding was forced into retirement.

properties.Title: Uruguay
properties.Descr_1: Uruguay. January 2 to 27. Forces from two United States warships landed to protect American property during a revolution in Montevideo.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. The Secretary of State requested a display of naval force along the Levant after a massacre of Americans at Jaffa and mistreatment elsewhere “to remind the authorities (of Turkey) of the power of the United States.”

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. The Secretary of State requested a display of naval force along the Levant after a massacre of Americans at Jaffa and mistreatment elsewhere “to remind the authorities (of Turkey) of the power of the United States.”

properties.Title: Paraguay
properties.Descr_1: Paraguay. Congress authorized a naval squadron to seek redress for an attack on a naval vessel in the Parana River during 1855. Apologies were made after a large display of force.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. Two hundred United States soldiers crossed the Rio Grande in pursuit of the Mexican bandit Cortina.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. July 31 to August 2. A naval force landed to protect American interests in Shanghai.

properties.Title: Angola, Portuguese West Africa
properties.Descr_1: Angola, Portuguese West Africa. March 1. American residents at Kissembo called upon American and British ships to protect lives and property during problems with natives.

properties.Title: Colombia (Bay of Panama)
properties.Descr_1: Colombia(Bay of Panama). September 27 to October 8. Naval forces landed to protect American interests during a revolution.

properties.Title: Japan
properties.Descr_1: Japan. July 16. The U.S.S. Wyoming retaliated against a firing on the American vessel Pembroke at Shimonoseki.

properties.Title: Japan
properties.Descr_1: Japan. July 14 to August 3. Naval forces protected the United States Minister to Japan when he visited Yedo to negotiate concerning some American claims against Japan, and to make his negotiations easier by impressing the Japanese with American power.

properties.Title: Japan
properties.Descr_1: Japan. September 4 to 14. Naval forces of the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Netherlands compelled Japan and the Prince of Nagato in particular to permit the Straits of Shimonoseki to be used by foreign shipping in accordance with treatie
properties.Descr2: s already signed.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. March 9 and 10. U.S. forces protected the lives and property of American residents during a revolution.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. From June 20 to July 7, U.S. forces punished an assault on the American consul at Newchwang.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. To protect American residents, General Sedgwick and 100 men in November obtained surrender of Matamoras. After three days he was ordered by U.S. Government to withdraw. His act was repudiated by the President.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. Marines occupied Managua and Leon.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. Marines occupied Managua and Leon.

properties.Title: Formosa
properties.Descr_1: Formosa. June 13. A naval force landed and burned a number of huts to punish the murder of the crew of a wrecked American vessel.

properties.Title: Japan (Osaka, Hiola, Nagasaki, Yokohama, and Negata)
properties.Descr_1: Japan (Osaka, Hiolo, Nagasaki, Yokohama, and Negata). February 4 to 8, April 4 to May 12, June 12 and 13. U.S. forces were landed to protect American interests during the civil war in Japan.

properties.Title: Uruguay
properties.Descr_1: Uruguay. February 7 and 8, 19 to 26. U.S. forces protected foreign residents and the customhouse during an insurrection at Montevideo.

properties.Title: Uruguay
properties.Descr_1: Uruguay. February 7 and 8, 19 to 26. U.S. forces protected foreign residents and the customhouse during an insurrection at Montevideo.

properties.Title: Colombia
properties.Descr_1: Colombia. April. U.S. forces protected passengers and treasure in transit at Aspinwall during the absence of local police or troops on the occasion of the death of the President of Colombia.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. June 17 and 18. U.S. forces destroyed the pirate ship Forward, which had been run aground about 40 miles up the Rio Tecapan.

properties.Title: Hawaiian Islands
properties.Descr_1: Hawaiian Islands. September 21. U.S. forces placed the American flag at half mast upon the death of Queen Kalama, when the American consul at Honolulu would not assume responsibility for so doing.

properties.Title: Korea
properties.Descr_1: Korea. June 10 to 12. A U.S. naval force attacked and captured five forts to punish natives for depredations on Americans, particularly for murdering the crew of the General Sherman and burning the schooner, and for later firing on other American small
properties.Descr2: boats taking soundings up the Salee River.

properties.Title: Colombia (Bay of Panama)
properties.Descr_1: Colombia (Bay of Panama). May 7 to 22, September 23 to October 9. U.S. forces protected American interests during hostilities between local groups over control of the government of the State of Panama.

properties.Title: Colombia (Bay of Panama)
properties.Descr_1: Colombia (Bay of Panama). May 7 to 22, September 23 to October 9. U.S. forces protected American interests during hostilities between local groups over control of the government of the State of Panama.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. United States troops crossed the Mexican border repeatedly in pursuit of cattle thieves and other brigands. There were some reciprocal pursuits by Mexican troops into border territory. Mexico protested frequently. Notable cases were at Remolina
properties.Descr2: in May 1873 and at Las Cuevas in 1875. Washington orders often supported these excursions. Agreements between Mexico and the United States, the first in 1882, finally legitimized such raids. They continued intermittently, with minor disputes, until 1896

properties.Title: Hawaiian Islands
properties.Descr_1: Hawaiian Islands. February 12 to 20. Detachments from American vessels were landed to preserve order and protect American lives and interests during the coronation of a new king.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. May 18. An American force was landed to police the town of Matamoras temporarily while it was without other government.

properties.Title: Egypt
properties.Descr_1: Egypt. July 14 to 18. American forces landed to protect American interests during warfare between British and Egyptians and looting of the city of Alexandria by Arabs.

properties.Title: Panama (Colon)
properties.Descr_1: Panama (Colon). January 18 and 19. U.S. forces were used to guard the valuables in transit over the Panama Railroad, and the safes and vaults of the company during revolutionary activity. In March, April, and May in the cities of Colon and Panama, the f
properties.Descr2: orces helped reestablish freedom of transit during revolutionary activity.

properties.Descr2: orces helped reestablish freedom of transit during revolutionary activity.

properties.Title: Korea
properties.Descr_1: Korea. June. A naval force was sent ashore to protect American residents in Seoul during unsettled political conditions, when an outbreak of the populace was expected.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. December 20. A display of force persuaded the Haitian Government to give up an American steamer which had been seized on the charge of breach of blockade.

properties.Title: Samoa
properties.Descr_1: Samoa. November 14, 1888, to March 20, 1889. U.S. forces were landed to protect American citizens and the consulate during a native civil war.

properties.Title: Hawaiian Islands
properties.Descr_1: Hawaiian Islands. July 30 and 31. U.S. forces protected American interests at Honolulu during a revolution.

properties.Title: Argentina
properties.Descr_1: Argentina. A naval party landed to protect U.S. consulate and legation in Buenos Aires.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. U.S. forces sought to protect American lives and property on Navassa Island.

properties.Title: Bering Strait
properties.Descr_1: Bering Strait. July 2 to October 5. Naval forces sought to stop seal poaching.

properties.Title: Chile
properties.Descr_1: Chile. August 28 to 30. U.S. forces protected the American consulate and the women and children who had taken refuge in it during a revolution in Valparaiso.

properties.Title: Hawaii
properties.Descr_1: Hawaii. January 16 to April 1. Marines were landed ostensibly to protect American lives and property, but many believed actually to promote a provisional government under Sanford B. Dole. This action was disavowed by the United States.

properties.Title: Brazil
properties.Descr_1: Brazil. January. A display of naval force sought to protect American commerce and shipping at Rio de Janeiro during a Brazilian civil war.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. July 6 to August 7. U.S. forces sought to protect American interests at Bluefields following a revolution.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Marines were stationed at Tientsin and penetrated to Peking for protection purposes during the Sino-Japanese War.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Marines were stationed at Tientsin and penetrated to Peking for protection purposes during the Sino-Japanese War.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. A naval vessel was beached and used as a fort at Newchwang for protection of American nationals.

properties.Title: Korea
properties.Descr_1: Korea. July 24, 1894 to April 3, 1896. A guard of marines was sent to protect the American legation and American lives and interests at Seoul during and following the Sino-Japanese War.

properties.Title: Colombia
properties.Descr_1: Colombia. March 8 to 9. U.S. forces protected American interests during an attack on the town of Bocas del Toro by a bandit chieftain.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. May 2 to 4. U.S. forces protected American interests in Corinto during political unrest.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. February 7 and 8. U.S. forces protected American lives and property at San Juan del Sur.

properties.Title: The Spanish-American War
properties.Descr_1: The Spanish-American War. On April 25, 1898, the United States declared war with Spain. The war followed a Cuban insurrection against Spanish rule and the sinking of the U.S.S. Maine in the harbor at Havana.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. November 5, 1898 to March 15, 1899. U.S. forces provided a guard for the legation at Peking and the consulate at Tientsin during contest between the Dowager Empress and her son.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. November 5, 1898 to March 15, 1899. U.S. forces provided a guard for the legation at Peking and the consulate at Tientsin during contest between the Dowager Empress and her son.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. American and British naval forces were landed to protect national interests at San Juan del Norte, February 22 to March 5, and at Bluefields a few weeks later in connection with the insurrection of Gen. Juan P. Reyes.

properties.Title: Samoa
properties.Descr_1: Samoa. February-May 15. American and British naval forces were landed to protect national interests and to take part in a bloody contention over the succession to the throne.

properties.Title: Philippine Islands
properties.Descr_1: Philippine Islands. U.S. forces protected American interests following the war with Spain and conquered the islands by defeating the Filipinos in their war for independence.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. May 24 to September 28. American troops participated in operations to protect foreign lives during the Boxer rising, particularly at Peking. For many years after this experience a permanent legation guard was maintained in Peking, and was strengt
properties.Descr2: hened at times as trouble threatened.

properties.Title: Colombia (State of Panama)
properties.Descr_1: Colombia (State of Panama). November 20 to December 4. U.S. forces protected American property on the Isthmus and kept transit lines open during serious revolutionary disturbances.

properties.Title: Colombia
properties.Descr_1: Colombia - April 16 to 23. U.S. forces protected American lives and property at Bocas del Toro during a civil war.

properties.Title: Colombia (State of Panama)
properties.Descr_1: Colombia (State of Panama). September 17 to November 18. The United States placed armed guards on all trains crossing the Isthmus to keep the railroad line open, and stationed ships on both sides of Panama to prevent the landing of Colombian troops.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 23 to 30 or 31. U.S. forces protected the American consulate and the steamship wharf at Puerto Cortez during a period of revolutionary activity.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. March 30 to April 21. A detachment of marines was landed to protect American interests in the city of Santo Domingo during a revolutionary outbreak.

properties.Title: Syria
properties.Descr_1: Syria. September 7 to 12. U.S. forces protected the American consulate in Beirut when a local Moslem uprising was feared.

properties.Title: Abyssinia
properties.Descr_1: Abyssinia. Twenty-five marines were sent to Abyssinia to protect the U.S. Consul General while he negotiated a treaty.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. U.S. forces sought to protect American interests and lives during and following the revolution for independence from Colombia over construction of the Isthmian Canal. With brief intermissions, United States Marines were stationed on the Isthmus
properties.Descr2: from November 4, 1903, to January 21, 1914, to guard American interests.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. January 2 to February 11. American and British naval forces established an area in which no fighting would be allowed and protected American interests in Puerto Plata and Sosua and Santo Domingo City during revolutionary fighting.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. January 2 to February 11. American and British naval forces established an area in which no fighting would be allowed and protected American interests in Puerto Plata and Sosua and Santo Domingo City during revolutionary fighting.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. January 2 to February 11. American and British naval forces established an area in which no fighting would be allowed and protected American interests in Puerto Plata and Sosua and Santo Domingo City during revolutionary fighting.

properties.Title: Tangier, Morocco
properties.Descr_1: Tangier, Morocco. “We want either Perdicaris alive or Raisula dead.” A squadron demonstrated to force release of a kidnapped American. Marines were landed to protect the consul general.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. November 17 to 24. U.S. forces protected American lives and property at Ancon at the time of a threatened insurrection.

properties.Title: Korea
properties.Descr_1: Korea. January 5, 1904, to November 11, 1905. A guard of Marines was sent to protect the American legation in Seoul during the Russo-Japanese War.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. September 1906 to January 23, 1909. U.S. forces sought to restore order, protect foreigners, and establish a stable government after serious revolutionary activity.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 18 to June 8. To protect American interests during a war between Honduras and Nicaragua, troops were stationed in Trujillo, Ceiba, Puerto Cortez, San Pedro, Laguna and Choloma.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 18 to June 8. To protect American interests during a war between Honduras and Nicaragua, troops were stationed in Trujillo, Ceiba, Puerto Cortez, San Pedro, Laguna and Choloma.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 18 to June 8. To protect American interests during a war between Honduras and Nicaragua, troops were stationed in Trujillo, Ceiba, Puerto Cortez, San Pedro, Laguna and Choloma.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 18 to June 8. To protect American interests during a war between Honduras and Nicaragua, troops were stationed in Trujillo, Ceiba, Puerto Cortez, San Pedro, Laguna and Choloma.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. March 18 to June 8. To protect American interests during a war between Honduras and Nicaragua, troops were stationed in Trujillo, Ceiba, Puerto Cortez, San Pedro, Laguna and Choloma.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. May 19 to September 4. U.S. forces protected American interests at Bluefields.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. January 26. American naval detachments were landed to protect American lives and interests during a civil war in Honduras.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. As the nationalist revolution approached, in October an ensign and 10 men tried to enter Wuchang to rescue missionaries but retired on being warned away, and a small landing force guarded American private property and consulate at Hankow. Marines
properties.Descr2: were deployed in November to guard the cable stations at Shanghai; landing forces were sent for protection in Nanking, Chinkiang, Taku and elsewhere.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. As the nationalist revolution approached, in October an ensign and 10 men tried to enter Wuchang to rescue missionaries but retired on being warned away, and a small landing force guarded American private property and consulate at Hankow. Marines
properties.Descr2: were deployed in November to guard the cable stations at Shanghai; landing forces were sent for protection in Nanking, Chinkiang, Taku and elsewhere.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. As the nationalist revolution approached, in October an ensign and 10 men tried to enter Wuchang to rescue missionaries but retired on being warned away, and a small landing force guarded American private property and consulate at Hankow. Marines
properties.Descr2: were deployed in November to guard the cable stations at Shanghai; landing forces were sent for protection in Nanking, Chinkiang, Taku and elsewhere.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. As the nationalist revolution approached, in October an ensign and 10 men tried to enter Wuchang to rescue missionaries but retired on being warned away, and a small landing force guarded American private property and consulate at Hankow. Marines
properties.Descr2: were deployed in November to guard the cable stations at Shanghai; landing forces were sent for protection in Nanking, Chinkiang, Taku and elsewhere.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. A small force landed to prevent seizure by the government of an American-owned railroad at Puerto Cortez. The forces were withdrawn after the United States disapproved the action.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. Troops, on request of both political parties, supervised elections outside the Canal Zone.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. June 5 to August 5. U.S. forces protected American interests on the Province of Oriente, and in Havana.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. June 5 to August 5. U.S. forces protected American interests on the Province of Oriente, and in Havana.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. August 24 to 26, on Kentucky Island, and August 26 to 30 at Camp Nicholson. U.S. forces protected Americans and American interests during revolutionary activity.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. August 24 to 26, on Kentucky Island, and August 26 to 30 at Camp Nicholson. U.S. forces protected Americans and American interests during revolutionary activity.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. November 18 to December 3. U.S. forces guarded the American legation at Constantinople during a Balkan War.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. August to November 1912. U.S. forces protected American interests during an attempted revolution. A small force, serving as a legation guard and seeking to promote peace and stability, remained until August 5, 1925.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. The disorders which began with the overthrow of the dynasty during Kuomintang rebellion in 1912, which were redirected by the invasion of China by Japan, led to demonstrations and landing parties for the protection of U.S. interests in China cont
properties.Descr2: inuously and at many points from 1912 on to 1941. The guard at Peking and along the route to the sea was maintained until 1941. In 1927, the United States had 5,670 troops ashore in China and 44 naval vessels in its waters. In 1933 the United States had
properties.Descr3: 3,027 armed men ashore. The protective action was generally based on treaties with China concluded from 1858 to 1901.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. September 5 to 7. A few marines landed at Ciaris Estero to aid in evacuating American citizens and others from the Yaqui Valley, made dangerous for foreigners by civil strife.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. January 29 to February 9, February 20 to 21, October 19. Intermittently U.S. naval forces protected American nationals in a time of rioting and revolution.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. January 29 to February 9, February 20 to 21, October 19. Intermittently U.S. naval forces protected American nationals in a time of rioting and revolution.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. January 29 to February 9, February 20 to 21, October 19. Intermittently U.S. naval forces protected American nationals in a time of rioting and revolution.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. June and July. During a revolutionary movement, United States naval forces by gunfire stopped the bombardment of Puerto Plata, and by threat of force maintained Santo Domingo City as a neutral zone.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. June and July. During a revolutionary movement, United States naval forces by gunfire stopped the bombardment of Puerto Plata, and by threat of force maintained Santo Domingo City as a neutral zone.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. Undeclared Mexican-American hostilities followed the Dolphin affair and Villa’s raids and included capture of Vera Cruz and later Pershing’s expedition into northern Mexico.

properties.Title: Haiti
properties.Descr_1: Haiti. July 28, 1915, to August 15, 1934. U.S. forces maintained order during a period of chronic political instability.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. American forces landed to quell a riot taking place on American property in Nanking.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. May 1916 to September 1924. American naval forces maintained order during a period of chronic and threatened insurrection.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. American troops were landed at Chungking to protect American lives during a political crisis.

properties.Title: World War I
properties.Descr_1: World War I. On April 6, 1917, the United States declared war with Germany and on December 7, 1917, with Austria-Hungary. Entrance of the United States into the war was precipitated by Germany’s submarine warfare against neutral shipping.

properties.Title: World War I
properties.Descr_1: World War I. On April 6, 1917, the United States declared war with Germany and on December 7, 1917, with Austria-Hungary. Entrance of the United States into the war was precipitated by Germany’s submarine warfare against neutral shipping.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. U.S. forces protected American interests during an insurrection and subsequent unsettled conditions. Most of the United States armed forces left Cuba by August 1919, but two companies remained at Camaguey until February 1922.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. After withdrawal of the Pershing expedition, U.S. troops entered Mexico in pursuit of bandits at least three times in 1918 and six times in 1919. In August 1918 American and Mexican troops fought at Nogales.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. After withdrawal of the Pershing expedition, U.S. troops entered Mexico in pursuit of bandits at least three times in 1918 and six times in 1919. In August 1918 American and Mexican troops fought at Nogales.

properties.Title: Mexico
properties.Descr_1: Mexico. After withdrawal of the Pershing expedition, U.S. troops entered Mexico in pursuit of bandits at least three times in 1918 and six times in 1919. In August 1918 American and Mexican troops fought at Nogales.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. U.S. forces were used for police duty according to treaty stipulations, at Chiriqui, during election disturbances and subsequent unrest.

properties.Title: Soviet Russia
properties.Descr_1: Soviet Russia. Marines were landed at and near Vladivostok in June and July to protect the American consulate and other points in the fighting between the Bolshevik troops and the Czech Army which had traversed Siberia from the western front. A joint pr
properties.Descr2: oclamation of emergency government and neutrality was issued by the American, Japanese, British, French, and Czech commanders in July. In August 7,000 men were landed in Vladivostok and remained until January 1920, as part of an allied occupation force.
properties.Descr3: In September 1918, 5,000 American troops joined the allied intervention force at Archangel and remained until June 1919. These operations were in response to the Bolshevik revolution in Russia and were partly supported by Czarist or Kerensky elements.

properties.Title: Soviet Russia
properties.Descr_1: Soviet Russia. Marines were landed at and near Vladivostok in June and July to protect the American consulate and other points in the fighting between the Bolshevik troops and the Czech Army which had traversed Siberia from the western front. A joint pr
properties.Descr2: oclamation of emergency government and neutrality was issued by the American, Japanese, British, French, and Czech commanders in July. In August 7,000 men were landed in Vladivostok and remained until January 1920, as part of an allied occupation force.
properties.Descr3: In September 1918, 5,000 American troops joined the allied intervention force at Archangel and remained until June 1919. These operations were in response to the Bolshevik revolution in Russia and were partly supported by Czarist or Kerensky elements.

properties.Title: Dalmatia
properties.Descr_1: Dalmatia. U.S. forces were landed at Trau at the request of Italian authorities to police order between the Italians and Serbs.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. Marines from the U.S.S. Arizona were landed to guard the U.S. Consulate during the Greek occupation of Constantinople.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. September 8 to 12. A landing force was sent ashore to maintain order in a neutral zone during an attempted revolution.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. March 14. A landing force was sent ashore for a few hours to protect lives during a disturbance at Kiukiang.

properties.Title: Guatamala
properties.Descr_1: Guatemala. April 9 to 27. U.S. forces protected the American Legation and other American interests, such as the cable station, during a period of fighting between Unionists and the Government of Guatemala.

properties.Title: Russia (Siberia)
properties.Descr_1: Russia (Siberia). February 16, 1920, to November 19, 1922. A Marine guard was sent to protect the United States radio station and property on Russian Island, Bay of Vladivostok.

properties.Title: Panama - Costa Rica
properties.Descr_1: Panama - Costa Rica. American naval squadrons demonstrated in April on both sides of the Isthmus to prevent war between the two countries over a boundary dispute.

properties.Title: Panama - Costa Rica
properties.Descr_1: Panama - Costa Rica. American naval squadrons demonstrated in April on both sides of the Isthmus to prevent war between the two countries over a boundary dispute.

properties.Title: Turkey
properties.Descr_1: Turkey. September and October. A landing force was sent ashore with consent of both Greek and Turkish authorities, to protect American lives and property when the Turkish Nationalists entered Smyrna.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Between April 1922 and November 1923 marines were landed five times to protect Americans during periods of unrest.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. February 28 to March 31, September 10 to 15. U.S. forces protected American lives and interests during election hostilities.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. February 28 to March 31, September 10 to 15. U.S. forces protected American lives and interests during election hostilities.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. September. Marines were landed to protect Americans and other foreigners in Shanghai during Chinese factional hostilities.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. January 15 to August 29. Fighting of Chinese factions accompanied by riots and demonstrations in Shanghai brought the landing of American forces to protect lives and property in the International Settlement.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. April 19 to 21. U.S. forces protected foreigners at La Ceiba during a political upheaval.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. October 12 to 23. Strikes and rent riots led to the landing of about 600 American troops to keep order and protect American interests.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. May 7 to June 5, 1926; August 27, 1926 to January 3, 1933. The coup d’etat of General Chamorro aroused revolutionary activities leading to the landing of American marines to protect the interests of the United States. United States forces cam
properties.Descr2: e and went intermittently until January 3, 1933.

properties.Title: Nicaragua
properties.Descr_1: Nicaragua. May 7 to June 5, 1926; August 27, 1926 to January 3, 1933. The coup d’etat of General Chamorro aroused revolutionary activities leading to the landing of American marines to protect the interests of the United States. United States forces cam
properties.Descr2: e and went intermittently until January 3, 1933.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. August and September. The Nationalist attack on Hankow brought the landing of American naval forces to protect American citizens. A small guard was maintained at the consulate general even after September 16, when the rest of the forces were with
properties.Descr2: drawn. Likewise, when Nationalist forces captured Kiukiang, naval forces were landed for the protection of foreigners November 4 to 6.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. August and September. The Nationalist attack on Hankow brought the landing of American naval forces to protect American citizens. A small guard was maintained at the consulate general even after September 16, when the rest of the forces were with
properties.Descr2: drawn. Likewise, when Nationalist forces captured Kiukiang, naval forces were landed for the protection of foreigners November 4 to 6.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. February. Fighting at Shanghai caused American naval forces and marines to be increased. In March a naval guard was stationed at the American consulate at Nanking after Nationalist forces captured the city. American and British destroyers later u
properties.Descr2: sed shell fire to protect Americans and other foreigners. Subsequently additional forces of marines and naval vessels were stationed in the vicinity of Shanghai and Tientsin.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. American forces were landed to protect American interests during the Japanese occupation of Shanghai.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. During a revolution against President Gerardo Machado naval forces demonstrated but no landing was made.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Marines landed at Foochow to protect the American Consulate.

properties.Title: Newfoundland, Bermuda, St. Lucia, Bahamas, Jamaica, Antigua, Trinidad, and British Guinea
properties.Descr_1: Newfoundland, Bermuda, St. Lucia, Bahamas, Jamaica, Antigua, Trinidad, and British Guiana. Troops were sent to guard air and naval bases obtained by negotiation with Great Britain. These were sometimes called lend-lease bases.

properties.Title: Greenland
properties.Descr_1: Greenland. Greenland was taken under protection of the United States in April.

properties.Title: Netherlands (Dutch Guiana)
properties.Descr_1: Netherlands (Dutch Guiana). In November the President ordered American troops to occupy Dutch Guiana, but by agreement with the Netherlands government in exile, Brazil cooperated to protect aluminum ore supply from the bauxite mines in Surinam.

properties.Title: Iceland
properties.Descr_1: Iceland. Iceland was taken under the protection of the United States, with consent of its government, for strategic reasons.

properties.Title: Germany
properties.Descr_1: Germany. Sometime in the spring the President ordered the Navy to patrol ship lanes to Europe. By July U.S. warships were convoying and by September were attacking German submarines. In November, the Neutrality Act was partly repealed to protect U.S. mi
properties.Descr2: litary aid to Britain.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. In October 50,000 U.S. Marines were sent to North China to assist Chinese Nationalist authorities in disarming and repatriating the Japanese in China and in controlling ports, railroads, and airfields. This was in addition to approximately 60,000
properties.Descr2: U.S. forces remaining in China at the end of World War II.

properties.Title: Trieste
properties.Descr_1: Trieste. President Truman ordered the augmentation of U.S. troops along the zonal occupation line and the reinforcement of air forces in northern Italy after Yugoslav forces shot down an unarmed U.S. Army transport plane flying over Venezia Giulia. Earl
properties.Descr2: ier U.S. naval units had been dispatched to the scene.

properties.Title: Palestine
properties.Descr_1: Palestine. A marine consular guard was sent to Jerusalem to protect the U.S. Consul General.

properties.Title: Berlin
properties.Descr_1: Berlin. After the Soviet Union established a land blockade of the U.S., British, and French sectors of Berlin on June 24, 1948, the United States and its allies airlifted supplies to Berlin until after the blockade was lifted in May 1949.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Marines were dispatched to Nanking to protect the American Embassy when the city fell to Communist troops, and to Shanghai to aid in the protection and evacuation of Americans.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Marines were dispatched to Nanking to protect the American Embassy when the city fell to Communist troops, and to Shanghai to aid in the protection and evacuation of Americans.

properties.Title: Formosa (Taiwan)
properties.Descr_1: Formosa (Taiwan). In June 1950 at the beginning of the Korean War, President Truman ordered the U.S. Seventh Fleet to prevent Chinese Communist attacks upon Formosa and Chinese Nationalist operations against mainland China.

properties.Title: China
properties.Descr_1: China. Naval units evacuated U.S. civilians and military personnel from the Tachen Islands.

properties.Title: Egypt
properties.Descr_1: Egypt. A marine battalion evacuated U.S. nationals and other persons from Alexandria during the Suez crisis.

properties.Title: Lebanon
properties.Descr_1: Lebanon. Marines were landed in Lebanon at the invitation of its government to help protect against threatened insurrection supported from the outside. The President’s action was supported by a Congressional resolution passed in 1957 that authorized suc
properties.Descr2: h actions in that area of the world.

properties.Title: The Carribean
properties.Descr_1: The Caribbean. 2d Marine Ground Task Force was deployed to protect U.S. nationals during the Cuban crisis.

properties.Title: Thailand
properties.Descr_1: Thailand. The 3d Marine Expeditionary Unit landed on May 17, 1962 to support that country during the threat of Communist pressure from outside; by July 30 the 5,000 marines had been withdrawn.

properties.Title: Cuba
properties.Descr_1: Cuba. On October 22, President Kennedy instituted a “quarantine” on the shipment of offensive missiles to Cuba from the Soviet Union. He also warned the Soviet Union that the launching of any missile from Cuba against any nation in the Western Hemispher
properties.Descr2: e would bring about U.S. nuclear retaliation on the Soviet Union. A negotiated settlement was achieved in a few days.

properties.Title: Laos
properties.Descr_1: Laos. From October 1962 until 1975, the United States played an important role in military support of anti-Communist forces in Laos.

properties.Title: Congo
properties.Descr_1: Congo. The United States sent four transport planes to provide airlift for Congolese troops during a rebellion and to transport Belgian paratroopers to rescue foreigners.

properties.Title: Vietnam War
properties.Descr_1: Vietnam War. U.S. military advisers had been in South Vietnam for a decade, and their numbers had been increased as the military position of the Saigon government became weaker. After citing what he termed were attacks on U.S. destroyers in the Tonkin G
properties.Descr2: ulf, President Johnson asked in August 1964 for a resolution expressing U.S. determination to support freedom and protect peace in Southeast Asia. Congress responded with the Tonkin Gulf Resolution, expressing support for “all necessary measures” the Pr
properties.Descr3: esident might take to repel armed attack against U.S. forces and prevent further aggression. Following this resolution, and following a Communist attack on a U.S. installation in central Vietnam, the United States escalated its participation in the war
properties.Descr4: to a peak of 543,000 military personnel by April 1969.

properties.Title: Dominican Republic
properties.Descr_1: Dominican Republic. The United States intervened to protect lives and property during a Dominican revolt and sent more troops as fears grew that the revolutionary forces were coming increasingly under Communist control.

properties.Title: Congo
properties.Descr_1: Congo. The United States sent three military transport aircraft with crews to provide the Congo central government with logistical support during a revolt.

properties.Title: Cambodia
properties.Descr_1: Cambodia. U.S. troops were ordered into Cambodia to clean out Communist sanctuaries from which Viet Cong and North Vietnamese attacked U.S. and South Vietnamese forces in Vietnam. The object of this attack, which lasted from April 30 to June 30, was to
properties.Descr2: ensure the continuing safe withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam and to assist the program of Vietnamization.

properties.Title: Evacuation from Cyprus
properties.Descr_1: Evacuation from Cyprus. United States naval forces evacuated U.S. civilians during hostilities between Turkish and Greek Cypriot forces.

properties.Title: Evacuation from Vietnam
properties.Descr_1: Evacuation from Vietnam. On April 3, 1975, President Ford reported U.S. naval vessels, helicopters, and marines had been sent to assist in evacuation of refugees and U.S. nationals from Vietnam.

properties.Title: Evacuation from Cambodia
properties.Descr_1: Evacuation from Cambodia. On April 12, 1975, President Ford reported that he had ordered U.S. military forces to proceed with the planned evacuation of U.S. citizens from Cambodia.

properties.Title: South Vietnam
properties.Descr_1: South Vietnam. On April 30, 1975, President Ford reported that a force of 70 evacuation helicopters and 865 marines had evacuated about 1,400 U.S. citizens and 5,500 third country nationals and South Vietnamese from landing zones near the U.S. Embassy i
properties.Descr2: n Saigon and the Tan Son Nhut Airfield.

properties.Title: South Vietnam
properties.Descr_1: South Vietnam. On April 30, 1975, President Ford reported that a force of 70 evacuation helicopters and 865 marines had evacuated about 1,400 U.S. citizens and 5,500 third country nationals and South Vietnamese from landing zones near the U.S. Embassy i
properties.Descr2: n Saigon and the Tan Son Nhut Airfield.

properties.Title: Mayaguez Incident
properties.Descr_1: Mayaguez incident. On May 15, 1975, President Ford reported he had ordered military forces to retake the SS Mayaguez, a merchant vessel en route from Hong Kong to Thailand with a U.S. citizen crew which was seized by Cambodian naval patrol boats in inte
properties.Descr2: rnational waters and forced to proceed to a nearby island.

properties.Title: Mayaguez Incident
properties.Descr_1: Mayaguez incident. On May 15, 1975, President Ford reported he had ordered military forces to retake the SS Mayaguez, a merchant vessel en route from Hong Kong to Thailand with a U.S. citizen crew which was seized by Cambodian naval patrol boats in inte
properties.Descr2: rnational waters and forced to proceed to a nearby island.

properties.Title: Lebanon
properties.Descr_1: Lebanon. On July 22 and 23, 1974, helicopters from five U.S. naval vessels evacuated approximately 250 Americans and Europeans from Lebanon during fighting between Lebanese factions after an overland convoy evacuation had been blocked by hostilities.

properties.Title: Zaire
properties.Descr_1: Zaire. From May 19 through June 1978, the United States utilized military transport aircraft to provide logistical support to Belgian and French rescue operations in Zaire.

properties.Title: Iran
properties.Descr_1: Iran. On April 26, 1980, President Carter reported the use of six U.S. transport planes and eight helicopters in an unsuccessful attempt to rescue American hostages being held in Iran.

properties.Title: El Salvador
properties.Descr_1: El Salvador. After a guerilla offensive against the government of El Salvador, additional U.S. military advisers were sent to El Salvador, bringing the total to approximately 55, to assist in training government forces in counterinsurgency.

properties.Title: Libya
properties.Descr_1: Libya. On August 19, 1981, U.S. planes based on the carrier U.S.S. Nimitz shot down two Libyan jets over the Gulf of Sidra after one of the Libyan jets had fired a heat-seeking missile. The United States periodically held freedom of navigation exercises
properties.Descr2: in the Gulf of Sidra, claimed by Libya as territorial waters but considered international waters by the United States.

properties.Title: Sinai
properties.Descr_1: Sinai. On March 19, 1982, President Reagan reported the deployment of military personnel and equipment to participate in the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai. Participation had been authorized by the Multinational Force and Observers Resol
properties.Descr2: ution, P.L. 97-132.

properties.Title: Lebanon
properties.Descr_1: Lebanon. On August 21, 1982, President Reagan reported the dispatch of 80 marines to serve in the multinational force to assist in the withdrawal of members of the Palestine Liberation force from Beirut. The Marines left September 20, 1982.

properties.Title: Lebanon
properties.Descr_1: Lebanon. On September 29, 1982, President Reagan reported the deployment of 1200 marines to serve in a temporary multinational force to facilitate the restoration of Lebanese government sovereignty. On Sept. 29, 1983, Congress passed the Multinational F
properties.Descr2: orce in Lebanon Resolution (P.L. 98-119) authorizing the continued participation for eighteen months.

properties.Title: Lebanon
properties.Descr_1: Lebanon. On September 29, 1982, President Reagan reported the deployment of 1200 marines to serve in a temporary multinational force to facilitate the restoration of Lebanese government sovereignty. On Sept. 29, 1983, Congress passed the Multinational F
properties.Descr2: orce in Lebanon Resolution (P.L. 98-119) authorizing the continued participation for eighteen months.

properties.Title: Egypt
properties.Descr_1: Egypt. After a Libyan plane bombed a city in Sudan on March 18, 1983, and Sudan and Egypt appealed for assistance, the United States dispatched an AWACS electronic surveillance plane to Egypt.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. In July 1983 the United States undertook a series of exercises in Honduras that some believed might lead to conflict with Nicaragua. On March 25, 1986, unarmed U.S. military helicopters and crewmen ferried Honduran troops to the Nicaraguan bor
properties.Descr2: der to repel Nicaraguan troops.

properties.Title: Honduras
properties.Descr_1: Honduras. In July 1983 the United States undertook a series of exercises in Honduras that some believed might lead to conflict with Nicaragua. On March 25, 1986, unarmed U.S. military helicopters and crewmen ferried Honduran troops to the Nicaraguan bor
properties.Descr2: der to repel Nicaraguan troops.

properties.Title: Chad
properties.Descr_1: Chad. On August 8, 1983, President Reagan reported the deployment of two AWACS electronic surveillance planes and eight F-15 fighter planes and ground logistical support forces to assist Chad against Libyan and rebel forces.

properties.Title: Grenada
properties.Descr_1: Grenada. On October 25, 1983, President Reagan reported a landing on Grenada by Marines and Army airborne troops to protect lives and assist in the restoration of law and order and at the request of five members of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean
properties.Descr2: States.

properties.Title: Persian Gulf
properties.Descr_1: Persian Gulf. On June 5, 1984, Saudi Arabian jet fighter planes, aided by intelligence from a U.S. AWACS electronic surveillance aircraft and fueled by a U.S. KC-10 tanker, shot down two Iranian fighter planes over an area of the Persian Gulf proclaimed
properties.Descr2: as a protected zone for shipping.

properties.Title: Italy
properties.Descr_1: Italy. On October 10, 1985, U.S. Navy pilots intercepted an Egyptian airliner and forced it to land in Sicily. The airliner was carrying the hijackers of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro who had killed an American citizen during the hijacking.

properties.Title: Libya
properties.Descr_1: Libya. On March 26, 1986, President Reagan reported to Congress that, on March 24 and 25, U.S. forces, while engaged in freedom of navigation exercises around the Gulf of Sidra, had been attacked by Libyan missiles and the United States had responded wi
properties.Descr2: th missiles.

properties.Title: Libya
properties.Descr_1: Libya. On April 16, 1986, President Reagan reported that U.S. air and naval forces had conducted bombing strikes on terrorist facilities and military installations in Libya.

properties.Title: Bolivia
properties.Descr_1: Bolivia. U.S. Army personnel and aircraft assisted Bolivia in anti-drug operations.

properties.Title: Persian Gulf
properties.Descr_1: Persian Gulf. After the Iran-Iraq War resulted in several military incidents in the Persian Gulf, the United States increased U.S. joint military forces operations in the Persian Gulf and adopted a policy of reflagging and escorting Kuwaiti oil tankers
properties.Descr2: through the Gulf. President Reagan reported that U.S. Navy ships had been fired upon or struck mines or taken other military action on September 23, October 10, and October 20, 1987 and April 19, July 4, and July 14, 1988. The United States gradually re
properties.Descr3: duced its forces after a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq on August 20, 1988.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. In mid-March and April 1988, during a period of instability in Panama and as pressure grew for Panamanian military leader General Manuel Noriega to resign, the United States sent 1,000 troops to Panama, to “further safeguard the canal, U.S. live
properties.Descr2: s, property and interests in the area.” The forces supplemented 10,000 U.S. military personnel already in Panama.

properties.Title: Libya
properties.Descr_1: Libya. On January 4, 1989, two U.S. Navy F-14 aircraft based on the U.S.S. John F. Kennedy shot down two Libyan jet fighters over the Mediterranean Sea about 70 miles north of Libya. The U.S. pilots said the Libyan planes had demonstrated hostile intent
properties.Descr2: ions.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. On May 11, 1989, in response to General Noriega’s disregard of the results of the Panamanian election, President Bush ordered a brigade-sized force of approximately 1,900 troops to augment the estimated 11,000 U.S. forces already in the area.

properties.Title: Andean Initiave in War on Drugs
properties.Descr_1: Andean Initiative in War on Drugs. On September 15, 1989, President Bush announced that military and law enforcement assistance would be sent to help the Andean nations of Colombia, Bolivia, and Peru combat illicit drug producers and traffickers. By mid
properties.Descr2: -September there were 50-100 U.S. military advisers in Colombia in connection with transport and training in the use of military equipment, plus seven Special Forces teams of 2-12 persons to train troops in the three countries.

properties.Title: Andean Initiave in War on Drugs
properties.Descr_1: Andean Initiative in War on Drugs. On September 15, 1989, President Bush announced that military and law enforcement assistance would be sent to help the Andean nations of Colombia, Bolivia, and Peru combat illicit drug producers and traffickers. By mid
properties.Descr2: -September there were 50-100 U.S. military advisers in Colombia in connection with transport and training in the use of military equipment, plus seven Special Forces teams of 2-12 persons to train troops in the three countries.

properties.Title: Andean Initiave in War on Drugs
properties.Descr_1: Andean Initiative in War on Drugs. On September 15, 1989, President Bush announced that military and law enforcement assistance would be sent to help the Andean nations of Colombia, Bolivia, and Peru combat illicit drug producers and traffickers. By mid
properties.Descr2: -September there were 50-100 U.S. military advisers in Colombia in connection with transport and training in the use of military equipment, plus seven Special Forces teams of 2-12 persons to train troops in the three countries.

properties.Title: Philippines
properties.Descr_1: Philippines. On December 2, 1989, President Bush reported that on December 1 U.S. fighter planes from Clark Air Base in the Philippines had assisted the Aquino government to repel a coup attempt. In addition, 100 marines were sent from the U.S. Navy bas
properties.Descr2: e at Subic Bay to protect the U.S. Embassy in Manila.

properties.Title: Panama
properties.Descr_1: Panama. On December 21, 1989, President Bush reported that he had ordered U.S. military forces to Panama to protect the lives of American citizens and bring General Noriega to justice. By February 13, 1990, all the invasion forces had been withdrawn.

properties.Title: Liberia
properties.Descr_1: Liberia. On August 6, 1990, President Bush reported that a reinforced rifle company had been sent to provide additional security to the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, and that helicopter teams had evacuated U.S. citizens from Liberia.

properties.Title: Saudi Arabia
properties.Descr_1: Saudi Arabia. On August 9, 1990, President Bush reported that he had ordered the forward deployment of substantial elements of the U.S. armed forces into the Persian Gulf region to help defend Saudi Arabia after the August 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.
properties.Descr2: On November 16, 1990, he reported the continued buildup of the forces to ensure an adequate offensive military option.

properties.Title: Saudi Arabia
properties.Descr_1: Saudi Arabia. On August 9, 1990, President Bush reported that he had ordered the forward deployment of substantial elements of the U.S. armed forces into the Persian Gulf region to help defend Saudi Arabia after the August 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.
properties.Descr2: On November 16, 1990, he reported the continued buildup of the forces to ensure an adequate offensive military option.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 18, 1991, President Bush reported that he had directed U.S. armed forces to commence combat operations on January 16 against Iraqi forces and military targets in Iraq and Kuwait, in conjunction with a coalition of allies and U.N. Securi
properties.Descr2: ty Council resolutions. On January 12 Congress had passed the Authorization for Use of Military Force against Iraq Resolution (P.L. 102-1). Combat operations were suspended on February 28, 1991.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 18, 1991, President Bush reported that he had directed U.S. armed forces to commence combat operations on January 16 against Iraqi forces and military targets in Iraq and Kuwait, in conjunction with a coalition of allies and U.N. Securi
properties.Descr2: ty Council resolutions. On January 12 Congress had passed the Authorization for Use of Military Force against Iraq Resolution (P.L. 102-1). Combat operations were suspended on February 28, 1991.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On May 17, 1991, President Bush stated in a status report to Congress that the Iraqi repression of the Kurdish people had necessitated a limited introduction of U.S. forces into northern Iraq for emergency relief purposes.

properties.Title: Zaire
properties.Descr_1: Zaire. On September 25-27, 1991, after widespread looting and rioting broke out in Kinshasa, U.S. Air Force C-141s transported 100 Belgian troops and equipment into Kinshasa. U.S. planes also carried 300 French troops into the Central African Republic a
properties.Descr2: nd hauled back American citizens and third country nationals from locations outside Zaire.

properties.Title: Sierra Leone
properties.Descr_1: Sierra Leone. On May 3, 1992, U.S. military planes evacuated Americans from Sierra Leone, where military leaders had overthrown the government.

properties.Title: Kuwait
properties.Descr_1: Kuwait. On August 3, 1992, the United States began a series of military exercises in Kuwait, following Iraqi refusal to recognize a new border drawn up by the United Nations and refusal to cooperate with U.N. inspection teams.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On September 16, 1992, President Bush stated in a status report to Congress that he had ordered U.S. participation in the enforcement of a prohibition against Iraqi flights in a specified zone in southern Iraq, and aerial reconnaissance to monitor
properties.Descr2: Iraqi compliance with the cease-fire resolution.

properties.Title: Somalia
properties.Descr_1: Somalia. On December 10, 1992, President Bush reported that he had deployed U.S. armed forces to Somalia in response to a humanitarian crisis and a U.N. Security Council Resolution determining that the situation constituted a threat to international pea
properties.Descr2: ce. This operation, called Operation Restore Hope, was part of a U.S.-led United Nations Unified Task Force (UNITAF) and came to an end on May 4, 1993. U.S. forces continued to participate in the successor United Nations Operation in Somalia (UNOSOM II)
properties.Descr3: , which the U.N. Security Council authorized to assist Somalia in political reconciliation and restoration of peace.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 19, 1993, President Bush said in a status report that on December 27, 1992, U.S. aircraft had shot down an Iraqi aircraft in the prohibited zone; on January 13 aircraft from the United States and coalition partners had attacked missile
properties.Descr2: bases in southern Iraq; and further military actions had occurred on January 17 and 18. Administration officials said the United States was deploying a battalion task force to Kuwait to underline the continuing U.S. commitment to Kuwaiti independence.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 19, 1993, President Bush said in a status report that on December 27, 1992, U.S. aircraft had shot down an Iraqi aircraft in the prohibited zone; on January 13 aircraft from the United States and coalition partners had attacked missile
properties.Descr2: bases in southern Iraq; and further military actions had occurred on January 17 and 18. Administration officials said the United States was deploying a battalion task force to Kuwait to underline the continuing U.S. commitment to Kuwaiti independence.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 19, 1993, President Bush said in a status report that on December 27, 1992, U.S. aircraft had shot down an Iraqi aircraft in the prohibited zone; on January 13 aircraft from the United States and coalition partners had attacked missile
properties.Descr2: bases in southern Iraq; and further military actions had occurred on January 17 and 18. Administration officials said the United States was deploying a battalion task force to Kuwait to underline the continuing U.S. commitment to Kuwaiti independence.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. On January 21, 1993, shortly after his inauguration, President Clinton said the United States would continue the Bush policy on Iraq, and U.S. aircraft fired at targets in Iraq after pilots sensed Iraqi radar or anti-aircraft fire directed at them

properties.Title: Bosnia
properties.Descr_1: Bosnia. On February 28, 1993, the United States began an airdrop of relief supplies aimed at Muslims surrounded by Serbian forces in Bosnia.

properties.Title: Bosnia
properties.Descr_1: Bosnia. On April 13, 1993, President Clinton reported U.S. forces were participating in a NATO air action to enforce a U.N. ban on all unauthorized military flights over Bosnia-Hercegovina.

properties.Title: Bosnia
properties.Descr_1: Bosnia. On April 13, 1993, President Clinton reported U.S. forces were participating in a NATO air action to enforce a U.N. ban on all unauthorized military flights over Bosnia-Hercegovina.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. In a status report on Iraq of May 24, President Clinton said that on April 9 and April 18 U.S. planes had bombed or fired missiles at Iraqi anti-aircraft sites that had tracked U.S. aircraft.

properties.Title: Iraq
properties.Descr_1: Iraq. In a status report on Iraq of May 24, President Clinton said that on April 9 and April 18 U.S. planes had bombed or fired missiles at Iraqi anti-aircraft sites that had tracked U.S. aircraft.

properties.Title: Somalia
properties.Descr_1: Somalia. On June 10, 1993, President Clinton reported that in response to attacks against U.N. forces in Somalia by a factional leader, the U.S. Quick Reaction Force in the area had participated in military action to quell the violence. On July 1 Presid
properties.Descr2: ent Clinton reported further air and ground military operations on June 12 and June 17 aimed at neutralizing military capabilities that had impeded U.N. efforts to deliver humanitarian relief and promote national reconstruction, and additional instances
properties.Descr3: occurred in the following months.

properties.Descr2: ent Clinton reported further air and ground military operations on June 12 and June 17 aimed at neutralizing military capabilities that had impeded U.N. efforts to deliver humanitarian relief and promote national reconstruction, and additional instances
